data.title: Atom crashes with C-v C-p copy paste from/to other apps in Ubuntu 14.10
data.body:
I recently updated to the newest atom 0.194 and the clipboard works with right click copy/paste but the keyboard shortcuts are not working correctly, and make atom crash.

Included is the crash stack trace: 

```
ProblemType: Crash
Architecture: amd64
CrashCounter: 1
CurrentDesktop: Unity
Date: Thu Apr 23 22:14:16 2015
DistroRelease: Ubuntu 14.10
ExecutablePath: /usr/share/atom/atom
ExecutableTimestamp: 1429668090
ProcCmdline:
 /usr/share/atom/atom --eval require('/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/coffee-cash/lib/coffee-cash.js').setCacheDirectory('/home/myuser/.atom/compile-cache/coffee');
 require('/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/coffee-cash/lib/coffee-cash.js').register();
 require('/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/node_modules/coffeestack/index.js').setCacheDirectory('/home/myuser/.atom/compile-cache/coffee/source-maps');
 require('/usr/share/atom/resources/app.asar/src/task-bootstrap.js');
ProcCwd: /home/myuser
ProcEnviron:
 LANGUAGE=en_US
 TERM=xterm-color
 PATH=(custom, no user)
 XDG_RUNTIME_DIR=<set>
 LANG=en_US.UTF-8
 SHELL=/bin/bash
```

data.title: Autocomplete snippets seem to be displayed in arbitrary order
data.body:
In language-javascript/snippets, there's an "f" snippet for an anonymous function, and language-todo/snippets has "fix" for a "fix me" comment. To see this:
1. Open a javascript file
2. Type "f"

The former should be offered as the first suggestion, as it's the best match, but instead it appears 6th on the list, behind fix, for, forin, forof and fun.

data.title: Atom becomes non-responsive to keyboard
data.body:
On Ubuntu 14.10, Atom v0.190.0

Not sure why, but I've had Atom stop taking any keyboard input several times. Usually after switching back to Atom from another application. Mouse still works but no keyboard input does anything. Only workaround is to restart Atom.

data.title: Update csslint version to 0.10.0 so that FreeBSD is happier.
data.body: csslint removed their architecture limitations in 0.10.0 and so it no longer stops building on FreeBSD.

data.title: Support OS X’s Create Window/Document from the Dock
data.body:
Small, nickpicky-issue: a lot of applications, especially document-based apps offer a quick way to create a new document/window directly from the dock. Terminal.app is a great example of this:
![](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2067774/7305813/cf4c82cc-e9ce-11e4-9499-2c8825376f73.png)

It’d be useful if Atom could do the same thing, but the current options are:
![screen shot 2015-04-23 at 3 41 19 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2067774/7305861/31aef76a-e9cf-11e4-9839-4557ae3f00b8.png)

data.title: Support OSX's 'Option + Command + Q' to quit the app without saving the application state
data.body:
I loved https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/1603! Thank you so much for adding it!

However, as far as I can tell, there is now currently no way to quit the Atom _without_ saving the application state.

Most OSX apps support the native menubar/shortcut for `Quit and Close All Windows` (hold down option to see it in the menubar):

![untitled](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1469659/7299076/9374b07e-e9cb-11e4-883d-10dedb4bcd77.png)

It would be great if Atom supported it too! This way, if I know that I don't want to open the same project next time I can just `⌥ ⌘ Q` out of it.

data.title: Fix #6466 by calling app.quit() before last window are closes.
data.body: `app.saveState()` was being called after the window was closed, resulting in no state being saved.

data.title: "Unhandled promise rejection" no longer shows up in the console.
data.body:
This is a regression. Up to and including Atom v0.188.0, if you had code like:

``` coffee
setTimeout(
  () -> Promise.reject('haha rejected'),
  0)
```

you would discover your error via the following in the console:

```
Unhandled promise rejection Promise
     __proto__: Promise
    [[PromiseStatus]]: "rejected"
    [[PromiseValue]]: "haha rejected"
```

which you could use to help debug your issue.

As of Atom v0.189.0, you see nothing. You can have chains and chains of `Promise.then()`, and if there is a failure in the middle, you now have no idea and have to start adding `.catch()` calls everywhere. It's madness.

I don't know what specifically causes the change, but here's what I have discovered thus far:
- Atom v0.189.0 (Apr 1) is built on atom-shell v0.22.3 (Mar 29) whereas Atom v0.188.0 (Mar 24) is built on atom-shell v0.21.3 (Mar 3).
- atom-shell v0.22.0 mentions **Upgrade to Chrome 41** in its release notes.
- https://github.com/iojs/io.js/pull/758 is a PR with a massive history, which I will not even to pretend to have read, but I believe it was closed on Feb 24 and it includes the following text in its initial comment:

> Implement unhandled rejection tracking for promises as
> specified in https://gist.github.com/benjamingr/0237932cee84712951a2
> 
> Fixes https://github.com/iojs/io.js/issues/256
> 
> Note that I did not implement any default action - so errors are still
> swallowed by default and many developers are therefore not going
> to discover the hooks.

Seems suspicious.

data.body: Bookmarks created successfully with Ctrl+Alt+F2 but I am configured jsFormat on **on save** after formatting Bookmarks removed.

data.title: Crystal support
data.body:
What do you guys think on adding Crystal syntax highlighting support for Atom?

http://crystal-lang.org/

Maybe the sublime text lib might help? https://github.com/manastech/sublime-crystal

data.title: Selecting text with option + shift + arrow behaves differently to other Mac apps
data.body:
Atom doesn't seem to follow Mac convention in certain cases. To reproduce:
1. Double click to highlight a word
2. Option + shift + left arrow
- In other apps, both words are now selected.
- In atom, the selection is cleared and the cursor is now at the start of the original word.

Similarly, if the 2. is replaced with command + shift + left arrow, in Atom the extended selection doesn't include the originally selected word as it would in other apps.

(This is clearly a minor issue; but it's frustrating if you're used to this pattern. Atom is fantastic overall!)

data.title: Preferred line length marker stays the same when changing font.
data.body: When I'm on my laptop I use 13pt Monaco. When I get to work, I change font to 16pt (because of larger screen, higher resolution) and the preferred line length (80 columns) stays the same. I need to close and reopen all files in order to get it to behave correctly.

data.body:
i want to change sidebar from left to right 
 where all the files are open , 
how can i do that

data.title: Manually updating Atom vs updates
data.body:
So I was impatient and downloaded the Atom installer instead of waiting for the 193 update today and since then Atom thinks it has to update and restart all the time. 
![2015-04-22_00-45-44](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/75278/7264158/fe5f8a60-e888-11e4-9084-721cb53aec9a.png)

Did it 3 times already, still happening. Looks like running the installer does not upgrade the local storage version field, I just looked and it was still set to 192, which explains the behaviour?

A combination of manually changing the version field in local storage and the update actually being available on the update servers seems to have fixed it. Still a problem someone should look into..

a) the installer not changing the version field
b) the updater freaking out when Atom is on a version that is newer than the one available on the update servers

data.title: Mark notifications public
data.body:
Put `atom.notifications` in the public API.

Mark `NotificationManager` and `Notification` as public as well and expose a minimal API.

Closes #5870

data.title: Updates fail due to write permissions
data.body:
Hello,

On OS X 10.10.3 I am having an issue updating Atom. When it tries to pull down the latest version of itself, I get the following error:

`There was an error checking for updates.
Could not create temporary directory: Permission denied`

I am running Atom 0.190. I will happily fix the file permissions, but I have no idea what directory it's trying to write to. I can't find any errors in the OS X Console.

Super low priority, and the error is decently verbose, but it would be nice to know which directory its trying to write to.

Thanks,

Austin

data.title: Emacs keybindings are not on by default
data.body:
In the docs, it currently says that you can move up and down with "ctrl+p" and "ctrl+n". But that doesn't work in atom out of the box:
"First of all, Atom ships with many of the basic Emacs keybindings for navigating a document. To go up and down a single character, you can use ctrl-P and ctrl-N."

See link (April 22, 2015):
https://atom.io/docs/latest/using-atom-moving-in-atom

Is this supposed to work? I am using Windows 7, 64bit.

data.title: Installer for Win 8.1 does not add atom nor apm to PATH
data.body:
I've made two installations of atom on fresh Windows installations. I used the Windows installer from atom.io. For Windows 7 I got both `atom` and `apm` in the PATH so I could call the directly from `cmd.exe`. But on Windows 8.1 they were not in the PATH.

I expected the same behavior on Windows 7 and Windows 8.1. 

Is this the intended behavior? Or am I missing something?

How should I do to get `atom` and `apm` in the PATH for Windows 8.1?

On Windows 8.1

```
C:\Users\Mikael>atom
'atom' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.

C:\Users\Mikael>apm
'apm' is not recognized as an internal or external command,
operable program or batch file.

C:\Users\Mikael>PATH
PATH=C:\Windows\system32;C:\Windows;C:\Windows\System32\Wbem;C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\
```

On Windows 7

```
C:\Users\mos>where atom
C:\Users\mos\AppData\Local\atom\bin\atom
C:\Users\mos\AppData\Local\atom\bin\atom.cmd

C:\Users\mos>where apm
C:\Users\mos\AppData\Local\atom\bin\apm
C:\Users\mos\AppData\Local\atom\bin\apm.cmd

C:\Users\mos>PATH
PATH=C:\Windows\system32;C:\Windows;C:\Windows\System32\Wbem;C:\Windows\System32\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\;C:\Program Files (x86)\Git\cmd;C:\Users\mos\AppData\Local\atom\bin
```

data.title: Move some Grim deprecation calls to correctly attribute them with packages
data.body:
_See https://github.com/atom/deprecation-cop/issues/36#issuecomment-94856987 for motivation._

@kevinsawicki @maxbrunsfeld I moved the two calls mentioned in the comment above :point_up: and that resolved the problem for those two calls. Here's how those two deprecations look now in Deprecation Cop:

![screen shot 2015-04-22 at 15 27 18](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/7275823/4f85a690-e906-11e4-8cac-a704d9412577.png)

:sparkles: -- notice that they are attributed to pdf-view, not to Atom core.

However, there are two other `Grim.deprecate` calls which are still being incorrectly attributed to Atom core -- the ones which check if the value returned from `onDidChangeModified` and `onDidChangeTitle` are `Disposable`s. 

![screen shot 2015-04-22 at 15 31 08](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/38924/7276006/59974f52-e907-11e4-9542-b5b935d43f1d.png)

Those two calls are [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/ecd04446434e47c505d7f1d3d8cb0fb76e91aa64/src/pane-view.coffee#L119) and [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/ecd04446434e47c505d7f1d3d8cb0fb76e91aa64/src/pane-view.coffee#L128). As far as I can tell, I can't apply the same approach to these because they check if the _return value_ has a specific type. So it needs to stay there, I _think_.

Also, the "magic" which helps us solve the problem for the two deprecations in this PR is that we explicitly pass a package name to Grim.deprecate to tell it what package is involved. That "magic" is implemented in [atom.workspace.getCallingPackageName()](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/ecd04446434e47c505d7f1d3d8cb0fb76e91aa64/src/workspace.coffee#L483). So, I tried calling this method from `pane-view.onActiveItemChanged()`, where the two deprecations checking for a `Disposable` return values are located, but that call returned `undefined`.

I'm not sure how to fix those two deprecations -- would love your help with those, if you have ideas. :pray: Also, maybe we can just remove them?

data.title: "Render on change" sporadically displayed in status bar
data.body:
I haven't figured out exact repro steps for this yet, but occasionally on startup I've seen "Render on change" in the status bar:

![screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/823545/7275754/b3023464-e8d3-11e4-893e-88494cb754e1.png)

It usually seems to be with an unsaved buffer on startup, but I'm not sure.

Atom 0.194.0
